questions.text:
Patient standing on one side has Trendelenburg sign positive. What is the Action of the muscle tested in Trendelenburg test?
1. Abduction
2. Flexion
3. Adduction
4. Internal rotation
questions.solution:
The Trendelenburg test assesses the function of the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles, which are the primary hip abductors.

  • Action of tested muscles: Abduction of the hip
  • Test interpretation:
    • Positive sign: When the patient stands on one leg, the opposite hip drops due to weakness of the hip abductors on the stance side (gluteus medius/minimus weakness or superior gluteal nerve injury).

Other options:

  • (A) 2, 3 (Flexion, Adduction) - Incorrect
    • Hip flexion (iliopsoas, rectus femoris) and hip adduction (adductors) are not tested in Trendelenburg test.
  • (C) 2, 4 (Flexion, Internal Rotation) - Incorrect
    • Hip internal rotation (gluteus medius/anterior fibers) is a minor function but not the main action tested.
  • (D) 1, 4 (Abduction, Internal Rotation) - Incorrect
    • Abduction is correct, but internal rotation is not the primary function tested.

Reference:Fundamentals of orthopedics by mohindra and jain page no-97

questions.text: What is the Treatment for Open fracture of femur?
questions.solution:
In cases of open fracture first fracture should be stabilized with external fixator and wound should be debrided.

Once wound gets healed and infection is cleared thereafter open reduction and internal fixation is done.

For open fractures Gustilo and Anderson classification is used for grading.

For open fractures like 3B antibiotics coated intramedullary nails are preferred over K wires.

  • With the evolution of available nails like antibiotic impregnated nails, intramedullary nailing is now performed even in 3B fractures.
  • Although there was initial phobia for the use of intramedullary nails, their usage has become widespread not only in grade 1 and 2 but even in grade 3 injuries.

Reference:Anderson JT, Gustilo RB. Orthopedics clinics of North America, 1980; 11:56

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with knee pain. The X-ray of his knee joint is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X ray shows an eccentric, epiphyseal expansile lytic lesion in the distal femur in a skeletally mature individual. This is the classical presentation of GCT.

Giant cell tumor :-

AGE (YR) :-20-40 Slight female predominance

SITE:-Distal femur>Proximal tibia>Distal radius

PRESENTATION:- Pain, Pathologic fracture (10%-30%), Egg shell cracking sound on tapping the lesion is heard

IMAGING:-

Eccentrically located in epiphysis

Purely radiolucent (no matrix formation) Soap bubble appearance

Usually no rim of reactive bone

Abuts subchondral bone

May exhibit cortical destruction with soft tissue extension

Metaphyseal in skeletally immature patients

HISTOLOGY:-

Multinucleated giant cells in sea of mononuclear cells

Nuclei of mononuclear cells identical to nuclei of giant cells

TREATMENT:-

Extended curettage Resection if residual bone stock inadequate

Consider radiation for spinal/ sacral tumors. Resection of pulmonary metastases

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 7thedition page no 232.

According to Ponseti technique cavus is corrected first. The order of correction is given by the mnemonic - CAVE- Cavus followed by Adductus and varus and equinus is corrected as the last step

Treatment is started within 1st week of life. The cavus aspect of the deformity is corrected first, followed by the adduction, then varus and lastly equinus. After every manipulation, an above-knee POP cast is applied, which is changed every 5-7 days. It is usually possible to correct all components of the deformity within 6 weeks. The equinus deformity often remains undercorrected, and can be treated by percutaneous tenotomy of tendoachilles. The cut tendoachilles regenerates spontaneous

Reference:Essential orthopedics by Maheshwari 7thedition page no 210.

choices.text: ACL, Medial collateral ligament & Medial Meniscus

questions.solution:
The unhappy triad(terrible triad) was described by American orthopedic surgeon D H O'Donoghue, in 1950.

He described simultaneous occurrence of tear of ACL, MCL and medial meniscus tear when lateral force applied to knee while the foot is fixed to the ground.

Reference:Manish kumar varshney 1stedition page no 889
